div.p: NARRATOR: Our brain's executive functions are subtle but very important. They allow us to make sense of things that we can't directly see or experience.
NARRATOR: They organize our memories, our sense of self and input about our environment. This allows us to make connections, prioritize, and plan how to act moment-by-moment.
NARRATOR: In the Green Phase, low-risk choices have no real impact on our brains.
NARRATOR: But in the Yellow Phase, high-risk choices begin to change the brain's frontal lobes where our executive functions are located.

NARRATOR: It gets harder to organize our thoughts, to plan, or to think clearly even after the alcohol or drug is out of our system. This effect lingers for a few hours to a few days, depending on how impaired we were.
NARRATOR: In the Orange Phase, ongoing high-risk choices begin to chronically interfere with our executive functions even when we're not drunk or high.
NARRATOR: For example, research has shown regular users of morphine, stimulants, marijuana or high-risk amounts of alcohol can have problems with planning, attention or memory.

NARRATOR: By the Red Phase, my high-risk choices have created a powerful mental link between using, pleasure and stress relief. Anytime I think of relaxing or celebrating, the alcohol or drug use spontaneously appears in my thoughts.
NARRATOR: It becomes hard to think of living my life without making high-risk choices.
NARRATOR: Over time, impulsive alcohol or drug use becomes compulsive due to a powerful motivation to use that builds in the brain and causes loss of control.
NARRATOR: At the same time, my abstract thinking becomes impaired, so I may not be able to see the connections between my choices, my values and my problems.

NARRATOR: It becomes harder to see the problem clearly. And the impairment makes it more difficult to remember things, problem solve, stay on task, or focus. The more high-risk choices I make, the worse this condition becomes.
